titleStmt.title: A Most true relation of the great and bloody battell fought upon Monday last neer the coast of England, by three of the Earl of Warwicks ships; namely, the James, George, and Gray-hound, against Col. Goring with 7. ships, who was comming to assist His Majesty against the Parl. declaring also the wonderfull victory which they hath obtained against the said Col. Goring, sinking three of his ships, and making all the rest to fly. Also how the states of Holland hath taken 30. sail of ships that were comming to England, laden with great store of arms and ammunition, which were sent from the Prince of Orange and the Dutch cavaleers to His Majesty.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Goring with 7. ships, who was comming to assist His Majesty against the Parl. declaring also the wonderfull victory which they hath obtained against the said Col. Goring, sinking three of his ships, and making all the rest to fly. Also how the states of Holland hath taken 30. sail of ships that were comming to England, laden with great store of arms and ammunition, which were sent from the Prince of Orange and the Dutch cavaleers to His Majesty.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A mo≈øt true RELATION Of the great and bloody BATTELL Fought upon Monday la≈øt neer the Coa≈øt of England, by three of the Earl of Warwicks ≈øhips; Namely, the James, George, and Gray-hound,

Again≈øt Col. Goring with 7. ≈øhips, who was comming to a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty again≈øt the Parl. Declaring al≈øo the wonderfull Victory which they hath obtained again≈øt the ≈øaid Col. Goring, ≈øinking three of his ≈øhips, and making all the re≈øt to fly.

Al≈øo how the States of Holland hath taken 30. Sail of ≈øhips that were comming to England, laden with great ≈øtore of Arms and Ammunition, which were ≈øent from the Prince of Orange and the Dutch Cavaleers to his Maje≈øty.

div.head: THE STATES OF HOLLAND And Zealand, Their Propo≈øitions to the King and Parliament, for an accommodation of Peace and Vnion betwixt the two Kingdoms of England and Scotland, and them ≈øelves, to oppo≈øe all Nations that ≈øhall come again≈øt them.
div.p:
THE States Generall for a long time have bin very ≈øcrupulous in declaring them≈øelves, but ≈øince they began to di≈øcern what the De≈øigns again≈øt the Parlament of England were (and if
brought to pa≈ø≈øe would in conclu≈øion prove their Raine.) Therefore the States of Holland and ‚Ä¢ ealand for the better preventing of the≈øe de≈øigns of forreign Nations, they unanimou≈øly con≈øented to have a generall meeting, at Am≈øterdam, where they concluded, and were more forward to advance this A≈ø≈øociation then before they were backward, being now ≈øen≈øible of the Prince of Orenge his forwardne≈ø≈øe in giving way that Arms, Ammunition, men, money, and other warlike provi≈øions ≈øhould be brought over ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ther, tending to the ruine of this pre≈øent Parliament.

And furthermore for the preventing of the≈øe de≈øigns and Con≈øpiracies, they are concluded for to declare their Re≈øolutions to the Parliament of ENGLAND, and to pre≈øent the≈øe following Propo≈øitions to that Grave and worthy A≈ø≈øembly. Viz.

THat whereas all forreign Nations having intelligence of the Di≈øtractions and the great Di≈øturbances that are now in this Kingdom, and the differences that are betwixt his Maje≈øty and his great and honourable A≈ø≈øembly the High Court of Purliament, have indeavoured and combined together, to rai≈øe a great power and ≈øtrength,
together with an invincible Sayle of ≈øhips, with a wicked Re≈øolution to come again≈øt the≈øe two Kingdoms of England and Scotland, to ca≈øt down and utterly de≈øtroy the true Prote≈øtant Religion: Therfore for the preventing of this damnable and Hell-bred Con≈øpiracie, the States Generall, and the States of Holland and Zealand doe unanimou≈øly de≈øire, that there may be a complyance with the Parliament, and that there may be an A≈ø≈øociation and firme union between them, and the Kingdoms of England and Scotland.

That as they under≈øtand, that in divers Places of Chri≈øtendom there are great preparations making for warre, for the de≈øtroying and ≈øubverting of all the Prote≈øtant Religion, ≈øo they mo≈øt earne≈øtly de≈øire, that the three States may joyn together to defend the ≈øame.

The States further declared unto the Hou≈øe, that they had made ≈øtop of all the provi≈øion provided there to be ≈øent to the
King, and are re≈øolved that no aid ≈øhall be ≈øent from thence.
The States are now in great controver≈øie with the Prince of Orange for his forwardne≈ø≈øe to ≈øend ≈øupplyes to the King, and for his combining with Papi≈øts in forrein parts.

It was al≈øo further ≈øignified to the honourable hou≈øes of Parliament, by Letters from Mr, Strickland, that the Prince of Orange had provided 30. ≈øayl of ≈øhips to tran≈øport Arms and Ammunition to his Maje≈øty the King of England, but the States having information of them, immediatly hindered his proceedings, and made ≈øtopping of the ≈øaid ≈øhipping.

div.head: The Parliaments An≈øwer to the States Propo≈øitions.
div.p:
UPon con≈øideration of this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, the Commons have orderd that a Letter of Thanks be returned to the States for
their fidelity to the Parliament, and to informe them that the Parliament do with much cheerfulne≈ø≈øe embrace their Propo≈øition for an a≈ø≈øociation, and firm Union betwixt the≈øe two Kingdomes of England and Scotland, and them, and that they will hazza ‚Ä¢ d their lives and fortunes in defence of the true Prote≈øtant Religion.
It is declared, that Collonell Goring with 1500. Germans and French hath taken ≈øhipping, and is comming for England to aid and a≈ø≈øi≈øt his Maje≈øty again≈øt the Parliament.

But the Parliaments Navie which is now at Sea, having intelligence of their comming, immediately hoy≈øted Sayle and made towards them, the James, the George, and the Gray-hound drew nearer and nearer to them, and let fly two or three pieces at Colonell Goring and his Cavaliers, which made them tremble at the noy≈øe of the Canon, in≈øomuch that they thought to have betook them≈øelves to flight.

But Colonell Goring thinking him≈øelfe ≈øufficient enough to encounter with them,
charged a broad ≈øide again≈øt them, but the James and the George comming up with much fury, ≈øunk two or three of Colonell Gorings ≈øhips, and held the re≈øt play for the ≈øpace of 4. hours, till at la≈øt the gorged Cavaleers began to betake them≈øelves to flight.
There were ≈ølain of the Cavaleers in this battle about the Number of 500. as it is ≈øuppo≈øed, and of our ≈øide 20. with little or no hurt to the ≈øhips.

p.hi: The Lords and Commons a≈ø≈øembled in Parl. do declare, that all ≈øouldiers that do commit any offence contrary to their Orders ≈øhall be brought to condigne puni≈øhment, and that they may be ≈øeverely proceeded again≈øt according to Law.
